Deep learning is used to provide forecasters with a powerful tool for monitoring high-dimensional time series of key physically relevant predictors and understanding how these predictors relate to one another and to short-term intensity changes in tropical cyclones (TCs). 

TCs are powerful storm systems that transfer energy from the upper levels of the world's oceans to the atmosphere. Increasing coastal populations and rising ocean temperatures due to climate change increase the dangers posed by TCs, making accurate prediction of TC trajectories and intensities critical for disaster preparation and response.

Track forecasting has made significant progress since the 1990s, but intensity forecasting, especially in the short-term 12-h and 24-h windows, has seen less improvement. Rapid intensity changes (30-knot intensity changes in 24 hours) are particularly difficult to predict. TC prediction and science rely on the relationships between the external environment, internal structure, and behavior of these storms. For example, vertical wind shear and TC convective patterns are known to relate to TC intensities.

Forecasters can access real-time TC observations, but new public forecasts must be issued every six hours by expert human forecasters. The human-in-the-loop pipeline requires that any forecasting guidance be easily understood by TC experts. The output of a method must be digestible by scientists in a short amount of time to be adopted by stakeholders at operational centers like the National Hurricane Center (NHC).

The NHC and other operational forecast centers use both physics-based models (dynamical models) and data-driven models (statistical models). The Statistical Hurricane Intensity Prediction Scheme (SHIPS) is a successful statistical-dynamical model that relates area averages of environmental fields and cloud-top temperatures from infrared (IR) imagery to future TC intensity change. IR imagery is available at high spatial and temporal resolutions from satellites like the Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellites (GOES).

Structure in IR imagery has long been known to relate to TC intensity, but area-averaged values commonly used in statistical models discard critical spatial information. The evolution of spatial structure in such fields correlates with intensity change, but unlocking this rich source of information in IR imagery without sacrificing interpretability remains an open problem.

We propose a framework to incorporate evolving spatial information into intensity forecasts by utilizing deep learning in the high-dimensional time series setting while considering the needs of end-users: forecasters and scientists. Our framework will provide something neither end-to-end models nor existing operational forecasts can: structural summaries or interpretable quantification of the convective structure of TCs in the form of one-dimensional functions, together with structural forecasts of the dynamic evolution of these summaries.

This new setup will provide forecasters with a powerful tool for monitoring high-dimensional time series of key physically relevant predictors, such as the eye-eyewall structure and symmetry of deep convection relative to the TC center, with the means to understand how the predictors relate to one another and to TC intensity change. Our approach involves two parallel pathways (A and B) that extract interpretable functions and use deep learning to propagate the structural state of the TC into the near future. These pathways allow forecasters to check the structural forecasts for agreement via quantitative error metrics and physical plausibility.
